course_outcomes: Understand the fundamentals of HTML elements, CSS Styles.
Apply HTML elements and their attributes for designing static web pages.
Create a web page by applying appropriate CSS styles and HTML elements.
Create dynamic web application and validate forms using JavaScript.

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: 1. HTML Lists, Links and Images.
2. HTML Tables, Forms and Frames.
3. HTML 5 and Cascading Style Sheets (inline, internal, external).
4. CSS Selector forms (Simple, Combinator, Pseudo-class, Pseudo-element, Attribute).
5. CSS with Color, Background, Font, Text and the CSS Box Model.
6. Applying JavaScript (internal/external), I/O, and Type Conversion.
7. JavaScript Pre-defined and User-defined Objects (document, window, array, math, string, regex, date).
8. JavaScript Conditional Statements and Loops.
9. Javascript Functions and Events for validation and calculations.

textbooks: Programming the World Wide Web, 7th Edition, Robet W Sebesta, Pearson, 2013.
WebProgrammingwithHTML5, CSSandJavaScript, JohnDean, Jones&Bartlett Learning, 2019 (Chapters 1-11).
Pro MERNStack: Full Stack Web App Development with Mongo, Express, React, and Node, Vasan Subramanian, 7th, APress, O’Reilly.

course_outcomes: Understand the fundamentals of Design Thinking and innovation.
Apply the design thinking techniques for solving problems in various sectors.
Analyse to work in a multidisciplinary environment.
Analyse the value of creativity.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Design Thinking
syllabus.topics: Introduction to elements and principles of Design. Design thinking process (empathize, analyze, idea & prototype), implementing the process in driving inventions, design thinking in social innovations. Tools of design thinking- person, costumer, journey map, brainstorming, product development.

syllabus.title: Innovation
syllabus.topics: Art of innovation, Difference between innovation and creativity, role of creativity and innovation in organizations. Creativity to Innovation. Teams for innovation, Measuring the impact and value of creativity.

syllabus.title: Product Design
syllabus.topics: Software reliability. Problem formation, introduction to product design, Product strategies, Product value, Product planning, product specifications. Innovation towards product design Case studies.

syllabus.title: Design Thinking in Business Processes
syllabus.topics: Design Thinking applied in Business & Strategic Innovation, Design Thinking principles that redefine business– Business challenges. Design thinking to meet corporate needs. Design thinking for Startups. Defining and testing Business Models and Business Cases. Developing & testing prototypes.

textbooks: Tim Brown, Change by design, 1/e, Harper Bollins, 2009.
Idris Mootee, Design Thinking for Strategic Innovation, 1/e, Adams Media, 2014.
reference_books: David Lee, Design Thinking in the Classroom, Ulysses press, 2018.
Shrrutin N Shetty, Design the Future, 1/e, Norton Press, 2018.
William lidwell, Kritinaholden, &Jill butter, Universal principles of design, 2/e, Rockport Publishers, 2010.
Chesbrough.H, The era of open innovation, 2003.

course_outcomes: Apply data preprocessing and visualization techniques for improved dataset analysis.
Analyse machine learning models, including Decision Trees and K-Nearest Neighbors.
Apply ensemble methods like Random Forest and Gradient Boosting.
Apply various clustering algorithms and the Expectation-Maximization algorithm, evaluating their effectiveness using appropriate metrics.

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Data Preprocessing (Normalization, Standardization, Encoding, PCA).
Task 2: Heuristic Search (Implement A* and AO* algorithms).
Task 3: Decision Trees and Model Explainability (Build, tune, visualize, and explain with SHAP).
Task 4: K-Nearest Neighbors with Hyperparameter Optimization (Grid/Random search for K and distance metric).
Task 5: Ensemble Methods (Random Forest and Gradient Boosting for classification and regression).
Task 6: Naïve Bayes for Text Classification with NLP Processing (TF-IDF vectorization).
Task 7: Support Vector Machines (SVM) with Kernel Trick (linear, polynomial, RBF).
Task 8: Linear and Logistic Regression Analysis.
Task 9: Multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) with Early Stopping and Regularization.
Task 10: Clustering Analysis with K-Means and DBSCAN.
Task 11: Advanced Clustering with Hierarchical and Spectral Clustering.
Task 12: Expectation-Maximization Clustering for Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM).

textbooks: Andrew Ng, Machine Learning Yearning. (more of a practical guide).
A. Geron, Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow, 2nd Edition, O’Reilly, 2019.
reference_books: K. P. Murphy, Machine Learning: A Probabilistic Perspective, MIT Press, 2012.
A. A.Patel, Hands-On Unsupervised Learning Using Python, O’Reilly Media, Inc., March 2019.

metadata.prerequisites: 23PC2104A Data Structures, 23AI&ML3304 Advanced Data Structures & algorithms Analysis
course_outcomes: Apply DDL, DML and DCL statements with integrity constraints
Design relational database and manipulate the same using simple and complex queries in SQL.
Develop Entity Relationship and the corresponding Relational models for the given real-world application.
Analyze database objects like Procedure, Functions, Triggers and Package using PL/SQL

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: DDL commands (CREATE, ALTER, DROP) with constraints.
Task 2: Queries using conversion, string, and date functions.
Task 3: Subqueries using ANY, ALL, IN, EXISTS, and set operations (UNION, INTERSECT).
Task 4: Queries using Joins, Aggregate Functions, GROUP BY, HAVING, and Views.
Task 5: Draw an ER diagram for an application and perform ER-to-Relational mapping.
Task 6: Implement normalization (1NF, 2NF, 3NF, BCNF, 4NF).
Task 7: Basic PL/SQL blocks with exception handling, COMMIT, ROLLBACK, SAVEPOINT.
Task 8: PL/SQL with NESTED IF, CASE expressions.
Task 9: PL/SQL with loops (WHILE, FOR) and error handling.
Task 10: PL/SQL Procedures with IN and OUT parameters.
Task 11: PL/SQL Stored Functions.
Task 12: PL/SQL Cursors (FOR UPDATE, WHERE CURRENT OF).
Task 13: PL/SQL Triggers (BEFORE/AFTER, Row/Statement, INSTEAD OF).
Task 14: Real-time database application for file uploads (Image, Video).

textbooks: Oracle: The Complete Reference by Oracle Press
Nilesh Shah, Database Systems Using Oracle, PHI, 2007
Rick F Vander Lans, Introduction to SQL, Pearson, 4th Edition, 2007.
reference_books: Gordon S Linoff, Data Analysis Using SQL and Excel, Wiley, 2nd Edition, 2016.
Joan Casteel, Oracle 12c:SQL, Cengage Learning, 2017.
J D Ullman, —Principles of database systems, Computer Science Press, 2001.

course_outcomes: Understand the fundamentals of Applied Math for deep learning approaches and paradigms.
Understand various Architectures of Deep Networks.
Analyze feed forward networks and Deep Neural networks.
Apply the deep learning techniques for various applications.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Neural Networks
syllabus.topics: Basics- Biological Neuron, Idea of computational units, McCulloch–Pitts unit and Thresholding logic, Linear Perceptron, Perceptron Learning Algorithm, Linear separability, Convergence theorem for Perceptron Learning Algorithm.

syllabus.title: Feedforward and Deep Neural Networks
syllabus.topics: Feed forward Networks: Multilayer Perceptron, Gradient Descent, Backpropagation, Empirical Risk Minimization, regularization, auto encoders. Deep Neural Networks: Difficulty of training deep neural networks, Greedy layer wise training.

syllabus.title: Training and Recurrent Neural Networks
syllabus.topics: Better Training of Neural Networks: Newer optimization methods for neural networks (Adagrad, adadelta, rmsprop, adam, NAG), second order methods for training, Saddle point problem in neural networks, Regularization methods (dropout, drop connect, batch normalization). Recurrent Neural Networks: Back propagation through time, Long Short-Term Memory, Gated Recurrent Units, Bidirectional LSTMs, Bidirectional RNNs.

syllabus.title: Convolutional and Generative Models
syllabus.topics: Convolutional Neural Networks: LeNet, AlexNet. Generative models: Restrictive Boltzmann Machines (RBMs), Introduction to MCMC and Gibbs Sampling, gradient computations in RBMs, Deep Boltzmann Machines. Recent trends: Variational Autoencoders, Transformers, GPT Applications: Vision, NLP, Speech.

textbooks: Ian Good fellow and Yoshua Bengio and Aaron Courville, Deep Learning, MIT Press, 1st Edition, 2016.
reference_books: R. Rojas, Neural Networks: A Systematic Introduction, 1st edition, Berlin, Germany: Springer-Verlag, 1996.
C. M. Bishop, Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning, 1st edition, New York, NY, USA: Springer, 2007.
F. Chollet, Deep Learning with Python, 1st edition, Shelter Island, NY, USA: Manning Publications Co., 2017.

course_outcomes: Understand the concepts related to network categories, topologies, and reference models.
Analyze error and flow control mechanisms in data link layer
Analyse subnetting and various routing protocols of network layer
Analyze transport layer and application layer protocols for specific applications.

syllabus.title: Introduction and Physical Layer
syllabus.topics: Types of Computer Networks, Reference Models- The OSI Reference Model, The TCP/IP Reference Model, A Critique of the OSI Model and Protocols, A Critique of the TCP/IP Reference Model. History of Internet. Physical Layer: Transmission Media, Guided and Un-guided media

syllabus.title: Data Link Layer
syllabus.topics: Data Link Layer Design Issues, Services Provided To the Network Layer, Error detecting and Error Correcting codes, Elementary Data Link Protocols, Sliding Window Protocols, HDLC, PPP. Multiple Access Protocols Wired Lans: Ethernet, Fast Ethernet, Gigabit Ethernet.

syllabus.title: Network Layer
syllabus.topics: Network Layer Design Issues, Routing Algorithms, Congestion, Congestion control algorithms. The Network Layer in the Internet, The IP Version 4 Protocol, IP Addresses- Classful, CIDR, NAT, IP Version 6 Protocol, Transition from IPV4 to IPV6.

syllabus.title: Transport and Application Layers
syllabus.topics: The Transport Layer: The Transport Layer Services, Transport Layer Protocols: UDP, TCP and SCTP. Application Layer: The World Wide Web, HTTP, Domain Name Space, Remote Loging, Electronic Mail and File Transfer.

textbooks: Andrew S Tanenbaum, David J Wetherall, Computer Networks, 5th Edition, Pearson Education, 2011.
Behrouz A.Fourozan, Data Communications and Networking. 4th Edition, TATA McGraw Hill, 2007.
reference_books: J.F. Kurose and K. W. Ross, Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach Featuring the Internet, 6th Edition, Pearson Education, 2012.

course_outcomes: Understand the basic components of an Operating System.
Apply CPU Scheduling techniques and mechanisms used for process synchronization.
Analyse Memory management techniques and methods for handling deadlocks.
Analyse File system Implementation techniques and protection mechanisms.

syllabus.title: System Structures, Processes, and Threads
syllabus.topics: Operating System Services, User and Operating-System Interface, system calls, Types of System Calls, system programs, operating system Design and Implementation, operating system structure, Building and Booting an Operating System, Operating system debugging. Processes: Process Concept, Process scheduling, Operations on processes, Interprocess communication. Threads and Concurrency: Multithreading models, Thread libraries, threading issues.

syllabus.title: CPU Scheduling and Synchronization
syllabus.topics: CPU Scheduling: Basic concepts, Scheduling criteria, Scheduling algorithms, multiple processor scheduling. Synchronization Tools: The Critical Section Problem, Peterson’s Solution, Mutex Locks, Semaphores, Monitors, Classic problems of Synchronization.

syllabus.title: Deadlocks and Memory Management
syllabus.topics: Deadlocks: system Model, Deadlock characterization, Methods for handling Deadlocks, Deadlock prevention, Deadlock avoidance, Deadlock detection, Recovery from Deadlock. Memory-Management Strategies: Introduction, Contiguous memory allocation, Paging, Structure of the Page Table, Swapping. Virtual Memory Management: Introduction, Demand paging, Copy-on-write, Page replacement, Allocation of frames, Thrashing. Storage Management: Overview of Mass Storage Structure, HDD Scheduling.

syllabus.title: File System and Protection
syllabus.topics: File System:File System Interface: File concept, Access methods, Directory Structure; File system Implementation: File-system structure, File-system Operations, Directory implementation, Allocation method. Free space management: File-System Internals: File-System Mounting, Partitions and Mounting, File Sharing. Protection:Goals of protection, Principles of protection, Protection Rings, Domain of protection, Access matrix.

textbooks: Silberschatz A, Galvin P B, Gagne G, Operating System Concepts, Wiley, 10th Edition, 2018.
Tanenbaum A S, Modern Operating Systems, Galgotia Publications Pvt. Ltd, 4th Edition, 2016.
reference_books: Stallings W, Operating Systems-Internals and Design Principles, Pearson, 9th Edition, 2018.
D.M Dhamdhere, Operating Systems: A Concept Based Approach, McGraw- Hill, 3rd Edition, 2013.

course_outcomes: Understand the theoretical foundations of computation through finite automata, regular languages, and their limitations.
Analyze and construct context-free grammars and pushdown automata for language parsing and recognition.
Demonstrate the capability to design lexical and syntax analyzers using formal methods and compiler construction tools.
Apply syntax-directed translation techniques and intermediate code generation strategies for compiler design.

syllabus.title: Finite Automata and Regular Expressions
syllabus.topics: Introduction to Finite Automata: Nondeterministic and Deterministic Finite Automata (NFA, DFA), Conversion of NFA to DFA. Regular Expressions: Finite Automata and Regular Expressions, Applications, Algebraic Laws, Conversion of Finite Automata to Regular Expressions. Pumping Lemma for Regular Languages.

syllabus.title: Context-Free Grammars and Turing Machines
syllabus.topics: Context-Free Grammars: Derivations, Parse Trees, Ambiguity. Push Down Automata: Definition, Equivalence of PDA’s and CFG’s. Turing Machines: Introduction, Formal Description, The language of a Turing machine. Undecidability.

syllabus.title: Lexical and Syntax Analysis
syllabus.topics: Introduction: The structure of a compiler. Lexical Analysis: Role of the Lexical Analyzer, Input Buffering, Recognition of Tokens, The Lexical-Analyzer Generator Lex. Syntax Analysis: Context-Free Grammars, Top-Down Parsing, Bottom-Up Parsing, Introduction to LR Parsing (Simple LR, More Powerful LR Parsers).

syllabus.title: Syntax-Directed Translation and Code Generation
syllabus.topics: Syntax-Directed Translation: Syntax-Directed Definitions (SDD), Evaluation Orders, Translation Schemes. Intermediate-Code Generation: Variants of Syntax Trees, Three-Address Code. Run-Time Environments: Stack Allocation of Space, Heap Management.

textbooks: John E. Hopcroft, Rajeev Motwani, Jeffrey D. Ullman, Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation, 3rd Edition, Pearson Education, 2006.
V. Aho, Monica S. Lam, Ravi Sethi, Jeffry D. Ullman, Compilers: Principles, Techniques and Tools, Alfred 2nd Edition, Pearson, 2006.
Mishra and Chandra shekaran, Theory of Computer Science– Automata languages and computation, 2nd Edition, PHI, 2006.
reference_books: Kamala Krithivasan, Introduction to Formal languages Automata Theory and Computation, Rama R, Pearson, 1st Edition, 2009.
JohnCMartin, Introduction to Languages and The Theory of Computation, TMH, 3rd Edition, 2003.
John R. Levine, Tony Mason, Doug Brown, Lex & Yacc, O’reilly, 2nd Edition, 1992.
Kenneth C. Louden, Thomson, Compiler Construction, Course Technology, 1st Edition, 1997.

course_outcomes: Understand key NLP concepts, including language modeling, tokenization, and part-of-speech tagging.
Understand NLP techniques like grammar parsing, dependency parsing, and word sense disambiguation.
Analyze syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic structures using probabilistic models and logic.
Apply the effectiveness of discourse analysis and lexical resources in NLP tasks.

syllabus.title: Introduction to NLP and Word-Level Analysis
syllabus.topics: Origins and challenges of NLP, Regular Expressions, Word Tokenization, Normalization, Lemmatization, Stemming, Sentence Segmentation, N-grams, Evaluating Language Models, Smoothing.

syllabus.title: Context-Free Grammars and Syntactic Analysis
syllabus.topics: Constituency, Context Free Grammars, Parse trees, Grammar Equivalence and Normal Forms (CNF), CKY Parsing Algorithm, Evaluating Parsers, Shallow parsing, Dependency trees.

syllabus.title: Semantics and Pragmatics
syllabus.topics: First-Order Logic, Syntax-Driven Semantic analysis, Word Senses, Relations between Senses, Thematic Roles, Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD), Word Similarity using Thesaurus and Distributional methods.

syllabus.title: Discourse and Lexical Analysis
syllabus.topics: Discourse segmentation, Centering theory, Coherence, Reference Phenomena, Anaphora Resolution, Coreference Resolution. NLP tools and Resources: Porter Stemmer, WordNet, PropBank, FrameNet, Brown Corpus.

textbooks: Daniel Jurafsky, James H. Martin, Speech and Language Processing: An Introduction to Natural Language Processing, Computational Linguistics and Speech, 2nd Edition, Pearson Publication, 2014.
Steven Bird, Ewan Klein and Edward Loper, Natural Language Processing with Python, First Edition, OReilly Media, 2009.
reference_books: Breck Baldwin, Language Processing with Java and Ling Pipe Cookbook, 1st Edition, Atlantic Publisher, 2015.
Richard M Reese, Natural Language Processing with Java, 2nd Edition, OReilly Media, 2015.
Nitin Indurkhya and Fred J. Damerau, Handbook of Natural Language Processing, 2nd Edition, Chapman and Hall/CRC Press, 2010.
Tanveer Siddiqui, U.S. Tiwary, Natural Language Processing and Information Retrieval, 3rd Edition, Oxford University Press, 2008.

course_outcomes: Understand how the Internet and Internet of Things (IoT) function at a conceptual level.
Analyze the constraints and opportunities of wireless and mobile networks used in IoT applications.
Apply basic sensing and measurement techniques to evaluate real-time network performance of connected devices.
Design prototype models for practical applications using IoT technologies.

syllabus.title: Overview of IoT
syllabus.topics: An Overview of Internet of things, IoT Technology, M2M Communication, Examples of IoTs, Design Principles For Connected Devices, Application Layer Protocols: HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, Telnet.

syllabus.title: IoT/M2M Systems and Standards
syllabus.topics: Business Models for Business Processes in IoT, IoT/M2M systems LAYERS AND designs standardizations, Modified OSI Stack for IoT/M2M Systems, ETSI M2M domains, Communication Technologies, Device Management Gateway.

syllabus.title: Web Connectivity and Data Management
syllabus.topics: Design Principles for Web Connectivity, Web Communication protocols, Message Communication protocols. Data Acquiring, Organizing and Analytics in IoT/M2M, Business Processes, Integration and Enterprise Systems.

syllabus.title: Cloud Platforms and Sensing Technologies
syllabus.topics: Data Collection, Storage and Computing Using a Cloud Platform for IoT/M2M Applications/Services, Everything as a service and Cloud Service Models, IoT cloud-based services (Xively, Nimbits), Sensor Technology, RFID, Wireless Sensor Networks.

textbooks: Rajkamal, Internet of Things: Architecture, Design Principles And Applications, McGraw Hill Higher Education, 2nd Edition, 2022.
A. Bahgya and V.Madisetti, Internet of Things, Univesity Press, 1ast Edition, 2015.
reference_books: A. McEwen and H. Cassimally, Designing the Internet of Things, 1st edition, Wiley, 2013.
C. Pfister, Getting Started with the Internet of Things, 1st edition, O’Reilly Media, 2011.

course_outcomes: Apply exploratory data analysis techniques using statistical and visualization tools to interpret and present different types of data effectively.
Apply data transformation techniques to prepare, analyze, and interpret datasets.
Apply descriptive statistical methods and grouping techniques to analyze and organize datasets effectively.
Analyze data using correlation and multivariate techniques and examine patterns in time series data.

syllabus.title: EDA Fundamentals and Visualization
syllabus.topics: Understanding data science, significance of EDA, Numerical and Categorical data. Software tools (NumPy, Pandas, SciPy, Matplotlib). Visual Aids for EDA: Line chart, Bar charts, Scatter plot, Area plot, Pie chart, Histogram.

syllabus.title: Data Transformation
syllabus.topics: EDA with Personal Email: Data cleansing, loading CSV, converting dates, removing NaN values. Data transformation techniques: Merging data frames, data deduplication, replacing values, handling missing data, renaming indexes, discretization and binning, outlier detection.

syllabus.title: Descriptive Statistics and Grouping
syllabus.topics: Descriptive Statistics: Distribution function, cumulative distribution function, Measures of central tendency (Mean, Median, Mode), Measures of dispersion (Standard deviation, Variance, Skewness, Kurtosis), percentiles, quartiles. Grouping Datasets: Understanding groupby(), data aggregation, pivot tables, cross-tabulations.

syllabus.title: Correlation and Time Series Analysis
syllabus.topics: Correlation: Univariate, bivariate, and multivariate analysis. Simpson’s paradox. Time Series Analysis: Fundamentals of TSA, characteristics of time series data. TSA with Open Power System Data: Data cleaning, time-based indexing, visualizing, grouping, and resampling time series data.

textbooks: Suresh Kumar Mukhiya, Usman Ahmed, Hands-On Exploratory Data Analysis with Python, Packt Publishing, 1st Edition, 2020.
reference_books: Ronald K. Pearson, Exploratory Data Analysis Using R, CRC Press, 1st Edition, 2020.
Radhika Datar, Harish Garg, Hands-On Exploratory Data Analysis with R: Become an expert in exploratory data analysis using R packages, 1st Edition, Packt Publishing, 2019.

course_outcomes: Understand the different software engineering process models.
Apply analysis model for different applications.
Apply design model for different application.
Apply different testing techniques.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Software Engineering and Process Models
syllabus.topics: The Nature of Software, Software Engineering Practice. The Software Process: Generic Process Model, Process Assessment. Process models: Prescriptive, Specialized, Unified, Personal and Team Process Models. Agile Development: Agility, Extreme Programming (XP), Other Agile Models.

syllabus.title: Requirements Engineering and Modeling
syllabus.topics: Requirements Engineering, Eliciting Requirements, Use Cases, Building the Analysis Model, Negotiating and Validating Requirements. Requirements Modeling: Scenario-Based Methods, UML Models. Class-based methods. Behavior, Patterns, and Web/Mobile Apps modeling.

syllabus.title: Software Design
syllabus.topics: Design Concepts, The Design Process and Model. Architectural Design: Styles, Considerations, and Decisions. Component-Level Design: Class-Based Components, Web/Mobile App component design. User Interface Design: The Golden Rules, Interface Analysis and Design Steps.

syllabus.title: Software Testing Strategies
syllabus.topics: A Strategic Approach to Software Testing, Test Strategies for Conventional, Object-Oriented, Web, and Mobile Apps. Validation testing, System testing, Debugging. Testing Conventional Applications: White Box Testing (Basis Path, Control Structure), Black-Box Testing.

textbooks: Roger S. Pressman, Bruce R.Maxim, Software Engineering a practitioners approach” 8th Edition, McGraw-Hill Publication 2019.
reference_books: Ian Somerville, Software Engineering, 9th Edition, Pearson Education. 2011.
Software Engineering principles and practice- Waman S Jawadekar, The Mc Graw Hill Companies.
Fundamentals of object-oriented design using UML Meiler page-Jones: Pearson Education.

course_outcomes: Understand the concepts of Web designing.
Apply the concepts of HTML5 and CSS to design static web pages.
Apply client side technologies to design interactive Web interfaces
Apply interactive server side scripting for a web application.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Web and Web Design
syllabus.topics: Concept of WWW, Internet, HTTP Protocol, Web browser and servers, Web 2.0. Web Design: Concepts of effective web design, issues (Browser, Bandwidth, Cache), Page Layout, User centric design, Sitemap, Planning and publishing.

syllabus.title: HTML and CSS
syllabus.topics: HTML: Basics, formatting, fonts, comments, color, hyperlinks, lists, tables, images, forms, XHTML, Meta tags, frames. Overview of HTML5. Style sheets: Need for CSS, syntax, using CSS, backgrounds, text, fonts, borders, boxes, margins, padding, positioning. Overview of CSS3.

syllabus.title: JavaScript and XML
syllabus.topics: JavaScript: Client side scripting, variables, functions, conditions, loops, Pop up boxes. Advance JavaScript: Objects, DOM manipulation, forms and validations. DHTML. XML: Introduction, uses, key components, DTD and Schemas. Transforming XML using XSL and XSLT.

syllabus.title: PHP and MySQL
syllabus.topics: PHP: Syntax, decision and looping, PHP and HTML, Arrays, Functions, Form processing, Files, Cookies and Sessions, Object Oriented Programming with PHP. PHP and MySQL: Connection to server, creating/selecting database, creating table, inserting data, queries, deleting data. phpMyAdmin.

textbooks: R. Moseley and M. T. Savaliya, Developing Web Applications, 2nd ed. New Delhi, India: Wiley India Pvt. Ltd., 2011.
reference_books: J. Sklar, Web Design Principles, 5th edition, Boston, MA: Course Technology Cengage Learning, 2012.
H. M. Deitel, P. J. Deitel, and T. R. Nieto, Internet & World Wide Web: How to Program, 3rd edition, Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson/Prentice Hall, 2004.
B. M. Harwani, Developing Web Applications in PHP and AJAX. New Delhi, India: Tata McGraw-Hill Education, 2010.

course_outcomes: Understand the design concepts and applications of Internet of Things
Understand Standards and Key Technologies in IoT.
Apply the steps of the design methodology in developing IoT applications using Raspberry Pi
Understand the Privacy, security and Vulnerabilities of internet of Things

syllabus.title: Introduction to Internet of Things
syllabus.topics: Introduction, Physical design of IoT, Logical Design of IoT, IoT Enabling technologies, IoT levels & Deployment templates. Domain Specific IoTs– Home Automation, Cities, Environment, Energy, Retail, Logistics, Agriculture, Industry, Health and Lifestyle.

syllabus.title: IoT, M2M, and Design Methodology
syllabus.topics: Introduction, M2M, Difference between IoT and M2M, SDN and NFV for IoT, Software Defined Networking, Network Function Virtualization. IoT Platforms Design Methodology: Introduction, IoT Design Methodology, Case Study on IoT System for Home Automation and Weather Monitoring.

syllabus.title: IoT Physical Devices and Endpoints
syllabus.topics: Basic building blocks of an IoT Device, Introduction to Raspberry Pi Board, Linux on Raspberry Pi, Raspberry Pi Interfaces (serial, SPI, I2C). Programming Raspberry PI with Python– Controlling LED, Interfacing LED and Switch, Interfacing a Light sensor (LDR).

syllabus.title: IoT Privacy, Security and Vulnerabilities
syllabus.topics: Introduction, Vulnerabilities, Security Requirements and Threat Analysis. Privacy, Use Cases and Misuse Cases, IoT Security Tomography and Layered Attacker model. Security models, profiles and protocols for IoT.

textbooks: Arshdeep Bahga , Vijay Madisetti, Internet of Things (A Hands-on Approach), 1st Edition, Universities Press Private Limited, 2014.
Raj Kamal, Internet of Things, Architecture and Design Principles, 1st Edition, McGraw Hill Education Private Limited, 2017.
reference_books: Matt Richardson & Shawn Wallace, Getting Started with Raspberry Pi, O’Reilly (SPD), 2014.
David Hanes, IOT Fundamentals, 1st Edition, CISCO Press, 2018.

course_outcomes: Implement deep neural networks to solve real world problems
Choose appropriate pre-trained model to solve real time problem
Interpret the results of two different deep learning models
Evaluate the deep learning models for optimized solutions

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Implement multi-layer perceptron for MNIST Handwritten Digit Classification.
Task 2: Design a neural network for binary classification of movie reviews (IMDB dataset).
Task 3: Design a neural Network for multi-class classification of news wires (Reuters dataset).
Task 4: Design a neural network for predicting house prices (Boston Housing dataset).
Task 5: Build a Convolutional Neural Network for MNIST Handwritten Digit Classification.
Task 6: Build a CNN for simple image classification (dogs and cats).
Task 7: Use a pre-trained CNN (VGG16) for image classification.
Task 8: Implement one-hot encoding of words or characters.
Task 9: Implement word embeddings for the IMDB dataset.
Task 10: Implement a Recurrent Neural Network for IMDB movie review classification.

textbooks: Ian Good fellow and Yoshua Bengio and Aaron Courville, Deep Learning, MIT Press, 1st Edition, 2016.
reference_books: R. Rojas, Neural Networks: A Systematic Introduction, 1st edition, Berlin, Germany: Springer-Verlag, 1996.
C. M. Bishop, Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning, 1st edition, New York, NY, USA: Springer, 2007.
F. Chollet, Deep Learning with Python, 1st edition, Shelter Island, NY, USA: Manning Publications Co., 2017.

course_outcomes: Implement UNIX concepts for creation of Shell Scripts
Apply CPU Scheduling algorithms, page replacement algorithms, thread implementation
Analyze Bankers Algorithm for Dead Lock avoidance and process Synchronization
Analyze the memory management techniques

syllabus.title: List of Tasks
topics: Task 1: Practicing of Basic UNIX Commands.
Task 2: Programs using UNIX operating system calls (fork, exec, getpid, exit, wait, close, stat, opendir, readdir).
Task 3: Simulate UNIX commands like cp, ls, grep.
Task 4: Simulate CPU scheduling algorithms (FCFS, SJF, Priority, Round Robin).
Task 5: Control port access using Semaphores and Monitors.
Task 6: Illustrate concurrent execution of threads using pthreads library.
Task 7: Solve producer-consumer problem using Semaphores.
Task 8: Implement memory allocation methods (First fit, Worst fit, Best fit).
Task 9: Simulate page replacement algorithms (FIFO, LRU, LFU).
Task 10: Simulate Paging Technique of memory management.
Task 11: Implement Bankers Algorithm for Dead Lock avoidance and prevention.
Task 12: Simulate file allocation strategies (Sequential, Indexed, Linked).
Task 13: Download and install nachos operating system and experiment with it.

reference_books: Silberschatz A, Galvin P B, Gagne G, Operating System Concepts, Wiley, 10th Edition, 2018.
Tanenbaum A S, Modern Operating Systems, Galgotia Publications Pvt. Ltd, 4th Edition, 2016.
Stallings W, Operating Systems-Internals and Design Principles, Pearson, 9th Edition, 2018.
D.M Dhamdhere, Operating Systems: A Concept Based Approach, McGraw- Hill, 3rd Edition, 2013.

course_outcomes: Implement router, template engine and authentication using sessions to develop application in ExpressJS.
Build a single page application using RESTful APIs in ExpressJS
Apply router and hooksin designing ReactJS application
Implement MongoDB queries to perform CRUD operations on document database

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: 1. ExpressJS: Routing, HTTP Methods, Middleware.
2. ExpressJS: Templating, Form Data.
3. ExpressJS: Cookies, Sessions, Authentication.
4. ExpressJS: Database connection (MongoDB) and RESTful APIs.
5. ReactJS: Render HTML, JSX, Function & Class Components.
6. ReactJS: Props, States, Styles, and Event Handling.
7. ReactJS: Conditional Rendering, Rendering Lists, and React Forms.
8. ReactJS: React Router for page navigation.
9. ReactJS: Using Hooks and sharing data between components.
10. MongoDB: Installation, Configuration, and CRUD operations.
11. MongoDB: Working with Databases, Collections, and Records.
12. Augmented Programs: Design a to-do list app and a quiz app.

textbooks: Vasan Subramanian, Pro MERN Stack: Full Stack Web App Development with Mongo, Express, React, and Node, 2nd edition, APress, O’Reilly.
Mike Cantelon, Mark Harter, T.J. Holowaychuk, Nathan Rajlich, Node.Js in Action, Manning Publications. (Chapters 1-11)
AzatMardan, React Quickly, Manning Publications, 2nd Edition, 2017.

course_outcomes: Identify the Societal problems.
Solve the problems.
Design of the problem/work plan.
Design of the prototype/model.

syllabus.title: Project Description
syllabus.topics: Carried out during summer vacation for six weeks after IV Semester. Students will go to the society (Villages/ Hospitals/Towns, etc,.) to identify a problem, survey literature for a feasible solution, and are encouraged to solve real life problems leading to innovative model building. This can be done in a group of students or as an individual.

course_outcomes: Execute rational pronunciation of speech sounds including accentuation.
Apply elements of listening comprehension in professional environments.
Develop the abilities of rational argumentation and skills of public speaking.
Demonstrate proficiency in the elements of professional communication including the competitive examination.

syllabus.title: Spoken Expression and Listening Comprehension
syllabus.topics: Speech Mechanism, Articulation of vowels and consonants, Patterns of Accentuation, Types and processes of Listening comprehension.

syllabus.title: Public Speaking
syllabus.topics: Group Discussion(Open and Monitored), Pyramid Discussion, PNI, Seminar Talk and Power Point Presentation.

syllabus.title: Professional Communication
syllabus.topics: Self Affirmation Advanced Composition including Memo and e-mail, R´esum´e Preparation, Corporate ethic of Non-Verbal Communication.

syllabus.title: Life Skills and Vocabulary for Competitive Examinations
syllabus.topics: Select Life Skills(50), Select Logies, Isms, Phobias and Manias (25 each), Sentence Completion and Double Unit Verbal Analogies (50 items), Fundamentals of Syllogisms(Descriptive and Pictorial).

textbooks: M. Cutts, Oxford Guide to Plain English, 7th impression, Oxford, UK: Oxford University Press, 2011.

Department of Phonetics and Spoken English, Exercises in Spoken English, 21st impression, Hyderabad, India: Central Institute of English and Foreign Languages (CIEFL), published by Oxford University Press, 2003.
reference_books: S. R. Covey, The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, 2nd edition, London, UK: Simon & Schuster UK Ltd (Pocket Books), 2004.
J. S. Brubacher, Eclectic Philosophy of Education: A Book of Readings, Englewood Cliffs, NJ, USA: Prentice-Hall, 1951.

course_outcomes: Learns to Implement Flutter Widgets and Layouts
Understand Responsive UI Design and with Navigation in Flutter
Knowledge on Widges and customize widgets for specific UI elements, Themes
Understand to include animation apart from fetching data

syllabus.title: List of Experiments
topics: 1. Install Flutter and Dart SDK; Write a program using HTTP methods.
2. Explore Flutter widgets (Text, Image, Container) and implement layouts (Row, Column, Stack).
3. Design a responsive UI that adapts to different screen sizes using media queries.
4. Set up navigation between screens using Navigator and named routes.
5. Implement state management using setState and Provider.
6. Create custom widgets and apply styling using themes.
7. Design a form with various input fields and implement validation.
8. Add animations to UI elements using Flutter’s animation framework.
9. Fetch data from a REST API and display it in the UI.
10. Write unit tests and use Flutter’s debugging tools.

textbooks: Marco L. Napoli, Beginning Flutter: A Hands-on Guide to App Development.
RapPayne, Beginning AppDevelopment with Flutter: Create Cross-Platform Mobile Apps 1st Edition, Apres
Richard Rose, Flutter & Dart Cookbook, Developing Full stack Applications for the Cloud, Oreilly.

course_outcomes: Understand the corporate etiquette.
Make presentations effectively with appropriate body language.
Be composed with positive attitude.
Understand the core competencies to succeed in professional and personal life.

syllabus.title: Analytical Thinking and Communication Skills
syllabus.topics: Self-Introduction, Shaping Young Minds (Listening Activity), Self–Analysis, Developing Positive Attitude, Perception; Verbal Communication, Non Verbal Communication (Body Language).

syllabus.title: Self-Management Skills and Etiquette
syllabus.topics: Anger Management, Stress Management, Time Management, Six Thinking Hats, Team Building, Leadership Qualities; Social Etiquette, Business Etiquette, Telephone Etiquette, Dining Etiquette.

syllabus.title: Standard Operation Methods and Verbal Ability
syllabus.topics: Note Making, Note Taking, Minutes Preparation, Email Letter Writing; Synonyms, Antonyms, One Word Substitutes, Correction of Sentences, Analogies, Spotting Errors, Sentence Completion, Course of Action, Reading Comprehension.

syllabus.title: Career-Oriented Skills
syllabus.topics: Group Discussion, Mock Group Discussions, Resume Preparation, Interview Skills, Mock Interviews.

reference_books: Mitra, B. K., Personality development and soft skills (Vol. 156). Oxford University Press, 2011.
Dhanavel, S. P, English and Soft Skills. Orient Blackswan Pvt Limited, 2011.
Aggarwal, R. S., A Modern Approach to Verbal & Non Verbal Reasoning. S. Chand, 2018.
Meenakshi, R. & Sharma, S, Technical Communication Principles and Practice, Oxford University Press, 2011.

course_outcomes: Understand the basics of writing technical reports, technical sentence formation, using transitions, and appropriate tenses for technical writing.
Understand the use of drafts, illustrations, grammar, spelling, readability, and writing in plain English for effective technical documentation.
Apply the use of word processor tools such as Table of Contents, citations, footnotes, comments, macros, and document protection.
Understand the nature of Intellectual Property and explain the process of patenting and international cooperation on Intellectual Property.

syllabus.title: Introduction to Technical Writing
syllabus.topics: An introduction to writing technical reports, technical sentences formation, using transitions, using tenses. Planning and Structuring: Planning the report, identifying reader(s), Voice, Formatting, Sections of a technical report, Minutes of meeting writing.

syllabus.title: Drafting and Finalizing Reports
syllabus.topics: The use of drafts, Illustrations and graphics. Final edits: Grammar, spelling, readability and writing in plain English. Proofreading and summaries. Presenting final reports: Printed presentation, Verbal presentation skills, Introduction to proposals.

syllabus.title: Using a Word Processor
syllabus.topics: Adding a Table of Contents, Indexing, Outlines, Comments, Tracking Changes, Footnotes and Endnotes, Inserting citations and Bibliography, Comparing/Combining Documents, Password protection, Using Macros.

syllabus.title: Intellectual Property Rights (IPR)
syllabus.topics: Nature of Intellectual Property: Patents, Designs, Trade and Copyright. Process of Patenting and Development: Technological research, innovation, patenting. International Scenario: International cooperation on Intellectual Property.

textbooks: Kompal Bansal & Parshit Bansal, “Fundamentals of IPR for Beginner’s”, 1st Ed., BS Publications, 2016.
William S. Pfeiffer and Kaye A. Adkins, “Technical Communication: A Practical Approach”, Pearson.
Ramappa,T., “Intellectual Property Rights Under WTO”, 2nd Ed., S Chand, 2015.
reference_books: Adrian Wallwork , English for Writing Research Papers, Springer New York Dordrecht Heidelberg London, 2011.
Day R, How to Write and Publish a Scientific Paper, Cambridge University Press, 2006.

syllabus.title: Project Description
syllabus.topics: The student should undergo an internship and simultaneously work on a project with well-defined objectives. At the end of the semester, the student should submit an internship completion certificate and a project report.
